Legolas has 2 eyes, spaced about 10cm apart. Assuming humanlike anatomy, those two eyes are connected to a common visual cortex, which is able to correlate image data coming from the two eyes. Humans actually do this to some extent - you can see sharper with both eyes open, than with either one alone.

If Legolas's visual cortex has crazy high processing power, he could use aperture synthesis techniques to see with an effective aperture of 10cm. Assuming Legolas has S-cones with a frequency response similar to us humans, he can resolve down to 11.7cm at a distance of 24km, improving to 8.8cm if he can see down to 300nm (shortest wavelength air is still transparent to).

One thing to note, though: all of this can be used to increase angular resolution, but not depth resolution. Actually discerning how tall the riders requires knowing their distance, or alternatively, having something of known height near the riders, to compare to.

Taken directly from a wiki page:
"The visual ability of birds of prey is legendary, and the keenness of their eyesight is due to a variety of factors. Raptors have large eyes for their size, 1.4 times greater than the average for birds of the same weight,[9] and the eye is tube-shaped to produce a larger retinal image. The resolving power of an eye depends both on the optics, large eyes with large appertures suffers less from diffraction and can have larger retinal images due to a long focal length, and on the density of receptor spacing. The retina has a large number of receptors per square millimeter, which determines the degree of visual acuity. The more receptors an animal has, the higher its ability to distinguish individual objects at a distance, especially when, as in raptors, each receptor is typically attached to a single ganglion.[1] Many raptors have foveas with far more rods and cones than the human fovea (65,000/mm2 in American kestrel, 38,000 in humans) and this provides these birds with spectacular long distance vision"

@Michael Groesbeck So you're implying light waves are oscillations of photon particles (given your drop of water analogy)? You know they are not, right? Wave theory implies light as a wave of electromagnetic fields. And it really doesn't matter what your opinion on this is, there is no debate "Wave theory vs Particle theory". It is widely accepted and tested in Physics that light (and, in fact, all matter) behave in a dualistic way. In fact, using the terms "wave" and "particles" is a severe linguistic limitation in discussing quantum objects, it's not like they can be one thing or the other. They are something else, which the words "wave" and "particle" can satisfy the purpose of understanding phenomena from time to time. Those terms were originally used for macroscopic entities, such as a particle of dust and a wave of water, but they become a lot less intuitive when describing things in the quantum scale.

Well, UV light is everything between 1 and 400 nm. Our atmospehere is actually reasonably transparent for the near UV range from 400 down to 200 nm. You did the math for XUV (20 nm) where the atmosphere is opaque but let us find out what Legolas could distinguish if he were able to see 200 nm for which the atmosphere is still reasonbly transparent (we will return to this later):

λ = 0,000 000 200 m
d = 0,005 m
Θ ≈ 1,22 ∙ 0,000 000 200 / 0,005
l = 24 000 m

1,1712 m ≈ 1,2 m

Legolas could distinguish objects larger than 1,12 meters at a distance of 24 km if he could see near UV. That would give you not only the ability to precisely count the horseman, but is sufficient to see if somebody is considerably taller than the rest of the group. However, you would not be able to say that it was their leader, as every detail about him (clothing, etc.) would be blurred out. Physics aside, there is also the question of physiology of the eyes. Given that Legolas has human sized eyes and pupils and could see near UV, he would need really tiny cone cells in his fovea to get a visual aucity that would actually make use of the near UV spectrum. Something on the order of 20/4 or better (just a guess I am lazy to do the mahts). But even if Legolas could see near UV (200 nm) and would have a visual aucity that matches the physical limits of his eyes and fovea, he still would have a big problem to look past atmospheric haze anyway. Especially in the UV range. So the "reasonably transparent" atmosphere is useful only at "short" distances (let us say up to 1 000 meter). However if Legolas could see in the near infrared spectrum, he could clearly see well beyound atmospheric haze (even the haze that we see in the visible spectrum), but the resolution in the near IR spectrum is even worse than visible, making diffraction a bigger problem. So the whole UV (near or far, 200 nm or 20 nm) is nice in theory, but over a distance fo 24 km I believe haze would have made it impossible to see anything useful. If it were useful for us humans, our eyes would have evolved in that way here on earth, in our atmosphere. Same with near IR. Not useful for us as a species. And both near UV and near IR give zero real world advantage in surviving and mating for our ancestors. I cannot imagine any evolutionary benefit for elves...

So, if we take Legolas at his word and if we assume a universe based on the same laws of physics as our own, it should be possible to calculate the minimum possible height that an elf with pupils fully dilated would have to be in order to see enough detail to count the individuals in the group and to estimate the height and hair colour of members of said group

Of course, if Legolas is now 500cm tall then we might consider that the riders are taller too, making observing them at a distance of five leagues ever so slightly less impressive﻿

Two eyes. In-brain-interferometry.

This is the limits of human-eye OPTICS, but the human brain mentally combines multiple images together over time, performing a sort of "super resolution" (yes its really called that) image stacking which gives you a clearer image than a single photo can. Notice that Legolas stares at the riders for some time, it's not instant. Also the brain is constantly doing pattern recognition, and is thus really good at recognising vague visual cues of things it's very familiar with seeing - like a horse rider. It's very good at guessing, it's essentially doing a huge multi-choice quiz at all times, all the possible answers are things it's seen before (so experience gives you an advantage, ie: the lifespan of elves) and it has to choose something even if it's blurry. Also you can recognise things by movement.

OK, two points of failure:

"Human-sized pupils". There's no evidence that this is the case.

"Extreme UV". There's no need to go that far. Bees use UV light all the time.

Let him see in near-UV, and give him pupils that are 50-100% larger than a human's, and there's no problem.

While we're at it, make his pupils contractile at will and add in the reflective surface that nocturnal animals all have. Elves can see clearly both by starlight and by much stronger light than normal daylight: their eyes are obviously more carefully engineered than human ones.

Of course, Legolas would have to assume the rider is taller and not plumper, but perhaps that's a justifiable assumption.  And he would have to have some way of knowing which rider it is, like the rider to the right of the left of the standard-bearer.  The standard bearer, with a large flag of unique colour should be discernible.

The following is based on my personal experience, not necessarily that of mainstream physics. You may find it insightful & interesting or dismiss it as fringe nonsense. At any rate, there is some evidence that this technique is used by the military and intelligence gatherers. And that it can be a learned skill. OK, that said, here's my take on Legolas:  Elves are remote viewers. Just as we can see images with our eyes closed, scenes can be viewed at a distance by using a subtle part of the brain which can be developed and/or trained. Eyesight is really brain sight, eyes are the normal lens, but the brain can also summon its inherent imaging capabilities to see details outside of normal time-space parameters.  Thus, imo, it's highly probable that elves have inherited this remote viewing ability and also develop it through their acceptance & recognition of it. You can call it magic but as Arthur C. Clarke noted in his third law: Any sufficiently advanced technology is indistinguishable from magic. The video above is clever & entertaining, but is using a physics that is bound by time-space. Elves can wrinkle time-space.  :)

What about the eyes of birds of prey?  They have rather fantastic distance vision in a package about the size of a human eye and their pupils are not remarkably large or anything.  I think it all depends on how similar/different elves are to humans.  Are elves basically a variety of human or something else?  Tolkien's writing about elves indicate they are radically different from humans in some ways, but as to how much of this is genetic and how much is magic is anyone's guess.

Also, the person who created this video made a slight error.  He acted as if the Riders of Rohan's visibility was based on their height.  Instead it should be based on the height of their head above the ground WHILE MOUNTED ON A HORSE.  How tall are the horses in question?  I don't know.  It might easily add 2 or 3 feet to their effective height.  A tall man's head might be 9 feet high while mounted on a horse.

Regarding the "elves are magic" explanation, elves in Tolkien's world really are magic, so it's not necessarily a cop out.

Well, this proves that a normal human with perfect vision cannot see that far. However, it does not answer the point that Legolas is an ELF, not a human. ...Not to mention the fact that they could see the Dead quite clearly in Return of the King, until the Dead chose to be seen. I read a lot of the comments, and most of them pointed out many things that could affect how different an Elvish eye is from a human's, such as pupil/iris size and how the brain processes the imagery sent from the eye. The books make no accurate mention of eye size, etc. and the movies are an INTERPRETATION of the books, using real humans to play the parts. (What I'm saying is that basing info off of actors and calling it fact is not really accurate. That being said, neither are the books). So Elves, in and of themselves, are more of a being of opinion and interpretation through what we see through the movies and books. They are primarily based off of fantasy and imagination.
I mean, looking back through time at the old stories, Elves were nothing more than wingless fairies that annoyed the heck out of everyone with teasing and rude jokes; they had no real definition until Tolkien came along and said "this is how I see them". Since he wrote those four Ages worth of story, his interpretation of the old myths have become a structure for every Elf imagined today, spring-boarded by Peter Jackson who gave a picture to the words. Granted that even then, Elves are still shown in various ways outside of Middle-Earth.
So, it's best not to compare Elves 100% to humans, as you have in this video, because they are NOT humans. That being said, Elves are not anatomically or physiologically defined, thus leaving who they REALLY are up to the reader via imagination, so we won't truly know exactly what they can or cannot see, nor how much is enhanced with magic (which is not used in a scientific analysis). All we know is that they have powerful eyes that can spot men riding horses across an open plain.
I believe that what you could have done was compare a human to Legolas by saying what a human with perfect vision could see at that distance, and then show what would have to be done to the human eye in order to see clearly at that range. (Legolas would merely be there for moral support, since, as I've said before, is scientifically undefined and living in a magical realm of imagination and opinions.)

I was also curious: at what point CAN the human eye see horsemen clearly at 24km? What sort of things would have to happen to the eye in order to see that range?

this is the sloppiest minutephysics episode i've ever seen. first off, your going about fantasy physica the wrong way. if the books state that Legolas can see a troop of horsemen 24 km away, and discern that one of them is taller than the other, then that statement in uniquely true. you start there, then reverse engineer it. second you make the improper assumption that Legolas is comparable to the average human. elves are exemplary better than humans in every way besides reproductively, and they are completely immortal (undying), and they obviously see better than a 5mm pinhole with greenlight streaming through. not to mention, its possible to discern size from a moving object, which the Riders where.
The fuck is the point of all this.

The equation given in the video uses the average size of a human pupil (5 mm). However, pupils can become approximately as wide as 9 mm when dilated (I've seen sources that list it as both 8 and 9, but I'm going to use the larger of the two just because). 
Assuming this size, the pupil can then distinguish objects no smaller than 0.004° instead of 0.007°, meaning that at a distance of 24 km, objects would become blurred only if they were shorter than about 1.675 m. That's easily a smaller number than the metrical height of a man sitting on a horse (the Riders). Assuming that Legolas has very human-like eyes and assuming that he had been covering his eyes with his hand for a few hours or so beforehand, it is completely possible for Legolas to have been able to clearly see the Riders from 24 km away, and to have discerned the approximate height of the leader clearly. 

Finally, the argument that keeps being brought up: Legolas is an elf, and his mysterious inner-elf workings in tandem with the magical nature of J.R.R. Tolkien's fantasy world make it so that it is entirely possible that he can clearly see farther than humanly possible.

These comments are a pain to read.  "What if he used magic?"  That was mentioned in the video.  And it's the only explanation that works (except possibly UV light).  

"But he has ELF eyes, not human eyes."  It doesn't matter.  This video didn't talk about eyes, it talked about focusing of light through a hole.  It's the same physics for a human eye or a camera lense or anything else that picks up light.  There are other factors that further limit how far away a person can differentiate something at a distance, but they can only limit eyesight further.  Again, the only way for him to see with more focus is with a different set of physics.  

"But what if his eyes were bigger."  That would definitely help, but I think if elves had huge eyes, it would have been mentioned in the books or shown in the movies.  Since (as far as I can remember) this wasn't mentioned or shown, it's safe to say he doesn't.  Saying otherwise would be silly since there's no evidence for it.  

"But what about hawks and other animals that see things far away?"  They can't see animals 24 kilometers (about 12 miles) either.  They still have excellent eyesight, but this would limit them as much as it would the elves.  

Again, if you're looking for an explanation, it's magic (or possibly UV light).  This video was meant to be an interesting look at physics in fiction.  It has real life uses, so it's not pointless.
"How Far Can Legolas See?"   Zero.  Elves aren't real.

Finally elf iris can be bigger than humans even with normal eye size so their pupils can be even bigger and their S cones (blue light) respond to shorter light waves so maybe they can see even sharper. Extra information about telescopes! Telescopes placed on the earths surface can not reach the diffraction limit due to "seeing". This seeing is the blurring of the image due to the atmosphere movement. The layer air above the telescope is not standing still, and this makes the light from the same source get somewhat spread out. Of course, satellite telescopes do not have this issue, and they can see at the diffraction limit.

Solutions for this problem include making a lot of very fast (short imaging time) images so the atmosphere did not have time to move. This does require a sufficiently bright source (else there will not be enough photons captured on the images). Another solution that is being developed is adaptive optics: by looking at a reference star or at a natrium laser coming from the telescope itself (that then gets reflected in the atmosphere), we can know how the seeing spreads out the light. We can then bend the telescopes mirror to adapt to the seeing. A feedback mechanism keeps reshaping the mirror to nullify the seeing.
